G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore confers jurisdiction on the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County because the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Boston, Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and the parties either reside or regularly conduct activity in Suffolk County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every operator and occupant of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others using the public ways, including bicyclists and pedestrians.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence in a premises-liability case dealing with duties of land occupiers toward entrants (licensees, invitees, trespassers). It does not address duties of operators or occupants of motor vehicles, nor the standard of care owed to other users of public ways such as bicyclists or pedestrians. Accordingly, this opinion does not provide authority for the specific motor-vehicle duty proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every operator and occupant of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others using the public ways, including bicyclists and pedestrians.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not concern duties of operators or occupants of motor vehicles toward other users of public ways. It involves premises liability and negligence claims arising from a scaffolding collapse at a residential construction site, focusing on causation and statutory liability under G.L. c. 143. There is no discussion of motor vehicles, public ways, bicyclists, or pedestrians, so it cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law specifically prohibits opening “the door of a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists.”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Bicycles are recognized as lawful vehicles on Massachusetts roadways and bicycle lanes, and bicyclists are entitled to the protections of the rules of the road.

G.L. c. 89, \u00a7 1.proposition: Bicycles are recognized as lawful vehicles on Massachusetts roadways and bicycle lanes, and bicyclists are entitled to the protections of the rules of the road.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violation of a safety statute enacted for the protection of the class of persons of which Plaintiff is a member (bicyclists using public ways) is evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The court expressly reiterates the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute like G.L. c. 138, § 69 does not create negligence per se but is "some evidence" of negligence as to the harms the statute was intended to prevent. Although the statute here concerns alcohol service rather than bicyclists specifically, the opinion clearly affirms the general principle that violation of such a protective statute, enacted for the safety of a class of persons, is evidence (but not conclusive proof) of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only "some evidence" of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).

Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1.proposition: Violation of a safety statute enacted for the protection of the class of persons of which Plaintiff is a member (bicyclists using public ways) is evidence of negligence.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1.support_reasoning: The court squarely states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute or ordinance is evidence of negligence, citing prior authority. Although this case involves a municipal building code and a tenant, not a bicyclist, the articulated principle is general and applies to safety enactments designed to protect a class of persons from the type of harm suffered. Thus it supports the broader proposition that violation of a safety statute protecting the plaintiff’s class (such as bicyclists on public ways) is evidence of negligence.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1.relevant_excerpt: “‘The general rule in Massachusetts is that violation of the safety statute or ordinance does not in itself give rise to a cause of action but is evidence of negligence.’ Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355 Mass. 665, 667 (1969). It is also the general rule that while the violation of a safety statute, ordinance or regulation is not conclusive on the issue of civil liability, it ‘…is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent.’ Follansbee v. Ohse, 293 Mass. 48, 52 (1935) …”

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593–94 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a motorist or vehicle occupant who opens a car door into oncoming traffic without taking reasonable precautions is negligent.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with premises liability and the duty of a landowner regarding an icy puddle on delivery premises. It does not address motorists, vehicle occupants, or the opening of car doors into traffic, nor does it discuss any standard of care related to such conduct. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition about negligence in opening a car door into oncoming traffic.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.relevant_excerpt: "The law imposes on a property owner 'a duty to maintain his property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”' ... Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition ... cannot be found to have violated its duty of care."

Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a motorist or vehicle occupant who opens a car door into oncoming traffic without taking reasonable precautions is negligent.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.support_reasoning: The Jorgensen opinion concerns whether Massachusetts law allows recovery of reputation damages in an ordinary negligence action and whether the plaintiffs proved causation for such damages. It does not address duties or standards of care for motorists or vehicle occupants opening car doors into traffic, nor any rule about negligence in that context. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about opening a car door into oncoming traffic being negligent under Massachusetts law.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.relevant_excerpt: In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. ... The existence of a duty and the breach of that duty are not at issue here: the parties are not appealing the initial jury's finding in the liability phase that Massport was negligent in maintaining Logan Airport on January 23, 1982.

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligent conduct was the direct and proximate cause of the collision and of Plaintiff’s resulting injuries and damages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case squarely rejects, rather than affirms, the idea that the defendant’s (Commonwealth’s) negligent conduct was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The court holds as a matter of law that the 1987 parole decision was not the proximate cause of the 1995 shooting, due to intervening and superseding causes, and orders dismissal of the negligence claims. Thus, it is contrary authority to the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the collision/injuries.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “[T]here is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision to parole MacNeil to the INS deportation warrant in 1987 was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries in 1995. The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.” (Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 321–22 (2002).)

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Even if the Court were to find that Plaintiff bore some degree of fault—which Plaintiff expressly denies—Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, would allow recovery so long as Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than that of Defendant, with damages reduced proportionally.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred and will continue to incur reasonable and necessary medical and dental expenses in an amount presently estimated at approximately One Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($1,500), and subject to revision according to proof at trial.

O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.raw_text: O’Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Mass. 586, 593–94 (1988)
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff lost earnings and wages in an amount presently estimated at approximately Eight Hundred Dollars ($800), and may experience future loss or diminution of earning capacity, all according to proof at trial.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns causation standards and jury instructions in an asbestos wrongful-death case, not the measure or recovery of lost wages or future diminished earning capacity. Nowhere does the court discuss damages calculations, lost earnings, or standards for proving wage loss. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about plaintiff’s lost earnings and possible future loss of earning capacity.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.relevant_excerpt: We have said before, and we repeat, “that if two or more wrongdoers negligently contribute to the personal injury of another by their several acts, which operate concurrently, so that in effect the damages suffered are rendered inseparable, they are jointly and severally liable.” Chase v. Roy, 363 Mass. 402, 408 (1973). Burke v. Hodge, 217 Mass. 182, 184-185 (1914). See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 780 F.2d 147, 157 (1st Cir. 1985).

DoCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and interference with her usual activities, recreation, and daily routines as a result of the injuries caused by Defendant’s negligence.
DoCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability of a manufacturer for negligent design and duty to warn, and reviews whether the overall damages award was excessive. Although the court lists various elements of the plaintiff’s damages (age, earnings, loss of hand function, pain, suffering, disfigurement, embarrassment), it does not specifically recognize or analyze ‘loss of enjoyment of life,’ ‘inconvenience,’ or ‘interference with usual activities, recreation, and daily routines’ as distinct compensable categories. Thus it does not clearly establish the proposition cited.
DoCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a tortfeasor is liable for all harm that is the natural and probable consequence of his negligent acts, including aggravation of pre‑existing conditions, if any.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts rule that a defendant whose tortious act combines with a pre‑existing or subsequently acquired disease is liable for all resulting harm, including aggravation, and applies that rule to uphold liability where the accident weakened the victim and made her unable to resist a later streptococcal infection. Although the case is framed in proximate cause terms and focuses on lowered vitality and subsequent disease, the court clearly affirms that a wrongdoer is responsible for the full extent of harm where his negligence interacts with pre‑existing or later conditions. This squarely supports the proposition about liability for natural and probable consequences, including aggravation of pre‑existing conditions.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.relevant_excerpt: “It is settled that, where an injury arising from a cause which entails liability on the defendant combines with a preexisting or a subsequently acquired disease to bring about greater harm to the plaintiff than would have resulted from the injury alone, the defendant may be liable for all the consequences. If the injury causes or contributes to cause the development of a preexisting disease, the person liable for the injury is liable also for the resulting aggravation. The wrongdoer may be held responsible for the harmful results of the combined effects of his wrongful act and the disease.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all economic and non‑economic losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.

McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..raw_text: McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152, 162–63 (1986)
McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all economic and non‑economic losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and taxable costs as allowed by law.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as allowed by G.L. c. 261 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure;
